headline: AI disruption prompts Australia's WiseTech to cut a third of global workforce
summary: Australian software firm WiseTech Global will axe about 2,000 jobs, nearly a third of its global workforce, in a ‌two‑year restructuring that could rank among the country's largest artificial intelligence-linked job reductions. Shares of ‌the company, which announced an estimate-beating first-half profit on Wednesday, closed 11.1% higher at A$47.74, while Australia's benchmark S&P ​ASX 200 rose 1.2%. The layoffs highlight how quickly AI is reshaping workplaces globally, as fast‑improving automation tools take over routine administrative work and handle complex coding tasks with increasing speed and precision, driving widespread adoption.

headline: 'Boring' energy, consumer staples stocks can buffer tech losses
summary: STORY: Meanwhile, tech stocks have been "a mixed bag," Mussio said, with most falling - including Microsoft, Nvidia, Meta Platforms and Amazon.He added that "it is worth noting" that companies such as Nvidia and Microsoft have market caps bigger than some entire sectors, "like energy, for example.""And so I think it's just a really good reminder for investors to be diversified, not just across asset classes... but within the asset classes," he said, and to have some exposure to the "boring sectors" that offer diversification from Big Tech.

headline: MercadoLibre Stock Climbs After Posting Mixed Q4 Results, Strong E-Commerce Growth
summary: MercadoLibre stock rose late Tuesday after the Latin America-focused e-commerce company reported fourth-quarter results that beat revenue expectations but were short of earnings forecast.  The Uruguay-based MercadoLibre said that it earned $11.03 per share for the December-ended quarter, down 12% from a year earlier and below the $11.50 per share that analysts polled by FactSet were forecasting.  In a letter to investors announcing the results, MercadoLibre said a 13% decline in net income was due to "normalization of our tax rate versus unusually low levels" in the fourth quarter of 2024.

raw.headline: MercadoLibre Stock Climbs After Posting Mixed Q4 Results, Strong E-Commerce Growth
raw.summary: MercadoLibre stock rose late Tuesday after the Latin America-focused e-commerce company reported fourth-quarter results that beat revenue expectations but were short of earnings forecast.  The Uruguay-based MercadoLibre said that it earned $11.03 per share for the December-ended quarter, down 12% from a year earlier and below the $11.50 per share that analysts polled by FactSet were forecasting.  In a letter to investors announcing the results, MercadoLibre said a 13% decline in net income was due to "normalization of our tax rate versus unusually low levels" in the fourth quarter of 2024.

headline: Italy watchdog bans Amazon unit from using staff personal data
summary: Italy's privacy ‌authority said ‌on Tuesday it had ​banned Amazon Italia Logistica from processing personal information ‌of ⁠1,800 workers at its Passo ⁠Corese logistics centre, near Rome. Amazon ​Italia ​Logistica ​must also ‌halt the processing of data collected through four video surveillance cameras installed ‌near bathrooms ​and ​in ​break areas, ‌the authority said ​in ​a statement.

headline: California seeks injunction to stop Amazon's alleged stifling of price competition
summary: California asked a state judge on Tuesday to stop Amazon.com from inflating prices for consumers through an ‌alleged campaign to bully merchants not to sell goods more cheaply elsewhere.  The ‌state's attorney general, Rob Bonta, sought a preliminary injunction in his 3-1/2-year-old antitrust lawsuit against ​Amazon, which also seeks to recoup ill-gotten profits.  "Amazon’s goal is to insulate itself from price competition by preventing lower retail prices in the market," Bonta said in a heavily redacted filing in the California Superior Court in San Francisco.

headline: Waymo's robotaxis now being dispatched in 10 major U.S. markets with expansion in Texas and Florida
summary: Waymo will begin dispatching its robotaxis in four more cities in Texas and Florida, expanding the territory covered by its fleet of self-driving cars to 10 major U.S. metropolitan markets.  The move into Dallas, Houston, San Antonio and Orlando, Florida, announced Tuesday, widens Waymo's early lead in autonomous driving while rival services from Tesla and the Amazon-owned Zoox are still testing their vehicles in only a few U.S. cities.  In contrast, Waymo's robotaxis already provide more than 400,000 weekly trips in the six metropolitan areas where they have been transporting passengers: Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Miami, Atlanta, and Austin, Texas.

raw.headline: Waymo's robotaxis now being dispatched in 10 major U.S. markets with expansion in Texas and Florida

In contrast, Waymo's robotaxis already provide more than 400,000 weekly trips in the six metropolitan areas where they have been transporting passengers: Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Miami, Atlanta, and Austin, Texas.

headline: OnTrac Appoints Akash Chauhan as Chief Operations Officer to Lead Service Expansion and Network Innovation
summary: OnTrac, the #1 alternative parcel carrier network, today announced that Akash Chauhan has been appointed Chief Operations Officer. Chauhan joins OnTrac as the company builds on record parcel volumes in 2025 and continues scaling its unified, coast-to-coast network serving retail brand, marketplace, and 3PL customers nationwide. His appointment reflects OnTrac's continued investment in operational efficiency, network performance, and long-term growth.

His appointment reflects OnTrac's continued investment in operational efficiency, network performance, and long-term growth.

headline: Goldman Team Says Asset-Heavy Stocks Outperform on AI Fears
summary: The Goldman team said their basket of capital intensive stocks whose economic value derives from physical assets has outperformed a capital light group reliant on human or digital capital by about 35% since the start of 2025.  Investors are increasingly turning to stocks with what the strategists called the “HALO effect,” for heavy assets and low obsolescence, in sectors like utilities, basic resources and energy, the team including Guillaume Jaisson said in a client note.

raw.headline: Goldman Team Says Asset-Heavy Stocks Outperform on AI Fears
raw.summary: The Goldman team said their basket of capital intensive stocks whose economic value derives from physical assets has outperformed a capital light group reliant on human or digital capital by about 35% since the start of 2025.  Investors are increasingly turning to stocks with what the strategists called the “HALO effect,” for heavy assets and low obsolescence, in sectors like utilities, basic resources and energy, the team including Guillaume Jaisson said in a client note.

headline: Amazon Pledges $12 Billion For Louisiana Data Centers, Aims To Create Over 2,000 Jobs
summary: Amazon.com Inc. (NASDAQ: AMZN) has declared a $12 billion investment in northwest Louisiana. The investment is earmarked for the development of cutting-edge data center campuses, which are projected to generate 540 full-time positions and support an additional 1,710 full-time equivalent roles in the community.
